titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mrs: Adams had a visit from Mrs: Krehmer, this morning; to whom the child was sent to pass the day, with her children— I had also visits from Mr: Montreal, and from Mr: Harris, with whom I walked, and called upon Mr: Dana and Mr: Coffin; but they were not at their lodgings.— I wrote one short letter, which was all the business I could accomplish— Dined with Mr: Smith at the Duke de Mondragone’s; he had a company of about fifteen persons— Mr: Six conversed with me on the subject of the changes about to take place in Holland; which it appears is to be united to France; and the king of which is said to have abdicated already— I pass’d the Evening at home.

2. Pass’d the principal part of this morning in writing— Walked round the City, through several Streets with which I was not acquainted; and for the first time remarked the Assignation Bank, the most elegant piece of architecture in the City— We all dined at home— In the Evening, Mrs: Adams went with Madame de Bray, and paid all her visits of form— I went with her to Madame de Bray’s; but there finding it not necessary as I had been assured it was to pay the visits with the Ladies, I went no farther— We had also visited at Mr: Bergien’s, but were not received.

3. The early part of this day not being interrupted by visits I employed in writing— In the interval between day-light, and dark I took a short visit— We all dined at home, and at about 10. in the Evening went to a Ball at the Chevalier de Bray’s— The French Ambassador was there, and invited us to a party at his house next Monday— Also a Ball— The Company consisted of his usual associates; but Count St: Julien, his aid the Baron de Mareschal, and a newly arrived Secretary, the Chevalier de Berks were also there— M. de Rumilly, one of the Secretaries of the French Embassy, who arrived yesterday from Paris was of the party— I played whist before supper, with Count Rzewuski, Monsieur de Vlodek and Mr: Hennings.— We came home between 2. and 3. in the morning.

4. Mr: Montreal, with his nephew came this morning, and I went with them to see a small collection of excellent pictures belonging to Monsieur Duval, who is the Court Jeweller, but whose most precious jewels are his Paintings— They are chiefly of the Flemish and Dutch schools, but he has an admirable Artemisia, by Guido— He has also one of the most perfect portraits of the Hamburg painter Denner— And an original portrait of Ariosto by Titian, a little repaired.— Excepting these his best pictures are Landscapes, which he says are of his favourite stile, and which I told him I was not worthy of seeing.— We dined at home; and in the Evening I went to the Concert of M. Thomasini at the Great Theatre— It being now the Lent Season, they give only concerts instead of plays— It was the first time I had been to the Theatre in this City, and I found it very dull— The music was indifferent.

5. Captain Beckford, and Mr: Shreve paid me a visit this morning.— The Captain, who came a day or two since, from Cronstadt, left four of his men there, sick with the small-pox— As I was going out, I met Mr: Donovan, who came for his Certificate; which I gave him accordingly— We dined at home; and in the Evening received visits from Mr: Dana, and Mr: Coffin, Mr: Baxter and Mr: Plumer— Also from Mr: Harris— They came about ten at Night, and stayed untill between one and two in the Morning; according to the usual visiting hours of this Country and this Season—

6. I had engaged with Mr: Krehmer, to go and dined with him this day at the English Club, or as Mr: Harris says, it should more properly be called, the club of the Nobility— But we had both forgotten this would be Christmas day— On recollecting which I wrote this morning an excuse to Mr: Krehmer— In the middle of the day I took a long walk to the Monastery of St: Alexander Nefsky, the front of which upon the river, I viewed from the river itself— On returning home I received an invitation to dinner, from the Baron de Blome, but sent an excuse— I dined at home, and in the Evening paid a number of visits— I found Mr: Six, Mr: Navarro, and the family at M: de Bray’s at home— Mr: Six appears much mortified at the turn which the affairs of his Country are taking— He supposes his mission here will soon be at an end; and knows not whether under the new order of things he will continue in public employment or not— Mr: Navarro lent me the pamphlet of Sir Francis d’Ivernois, of which General Stedingk, and Count Romanzoff had spoken to me; and a couple more English newspapers— At Madame de Bray’s I found Count Schenck—M. Ouvaroff, and M. Lajard— Count Schenck told me from Countess Golowkin, the owner of the house in which Mr: Six lives, that when he should go, the house should be at my service, if I wished to take it.— On returning home about 11. this Evening, I received a note from Count Romanzoff, informing me that he should dispatch a Courier the day after to-morrow, who would take any letters or dispatches, I might wish to send either to Paris, or to America.

7. From the moment when I rose this morning, just at daylight, untill nine this Evening, with the exception of half an hour at breakfast, and an hour at dinner, I was writing to the Secretary of State, and preparing packets for America, and for General Armstrong at Paris— Between 9 and 10. I went myself to Count Romanzoff’s Hotel, and left the Packets to be delivered to him— The remainder of the Evening I pass’d at Mr: Krehmer’s, where the Ladies had gone before me— There was a company of twenty-five or thirty persons—mostly dancers; to the musick of a forte-piano, played by a young officer of the company— Count St: Julien, Count Einsiedel, and Mr: d’Alopéus were there— I played whist with Mr: Krehmer, Mr: A. J. Smith, and Mr: Hennings— Some American Gentlemen were there— Among them, a Mr: M’Murtry of Philadelphia; a young Gentleman just arrived from Königsberg.— The Ball commenced anew after supper; and it was past two in the morning before we came home— Count St: Julien told me this Evening, of the news from Paris; that the Emperor Napoleon, is divorced from the Empress Josephine, and intends to marry a Princess of Saxony, about sixteen years of age; daughter of Prince Maximilian; the king’s brother.

8. We all went to a Ball this Evening at the French Ambassadors; after calling and leaving Cards at Princess Waezemsky’s— It being her birth-day, the Ball was given in honour of her. There were about a hundred and thirty persons there. The Supper was served about 2. O’Clock in the morning, and we came home about 4. leaving the company still dancing— I had much conversation with Count Soltikoff; the adjoint Minister of foreign affairs; a man of about forty—of grave manners; very reserved, but always ready to converse— He spoke to me about d’Ivernois’s late pamphlet; and asked me, what I thought its weak part— But he did not give me his own opinion— At Supper I sat next to Count Chernicheff a Young officer, about 25 years old, who has been repeatedly sent by the Emperor in special missions, about the person of the Emperor of Austria, and of the Emperor of France— He has been during the whole of the last Campaign, with Napoleon, and in his immediate family—constantly the companion of his table; and sleeping in his tent— He told me that he had been present at eight pitched battles— Among which were those of Eylau, Friedland,
Essling and Wagram— That of Essling he said was totally lost, “mais grandement”—by the French. And that it was entirely the fault of the Austrians that they did not take advantage of it— He said that the military reputation of the Archduke Charles was irretrievably lost, and that all the present misfortunes were imputable to him, almost alone.— He told me several particulars relating personally to Napoleon— I asked him if he was subject to the epilepsy— He hesitated about answering—but finally said, not to his knowledge— Then casting his eyes on both sides, as if fearful any body might hear, he said “il a la galle rentrée.” He added that he slept little—waked often in the night, and would rise in his bed—speak—give some order, and then go to sleep again— The Duke de Mondragone told me it was not certain whether he was to marry a princess of Saxony, or of this Country.

9. This morning was employed entirely, and untill 5. in the afternoon in paying visits; chiefly return visits to American Gentlemen. I also called upon Mr: Six, and Mr: Navarro— Mr: Six says, it is certainly not a Russian Princess that the Emperor Napoléon is to marry— That the imperial family here; and especially the Empress-mother never would consent to it— That two years ago, he wanted to marry the grand-duchess Catherine; who though the most ambitious woman in the world, absolutely refused to have him— The Grand-Duchess Catherine is her grand-mother over again— If any thing should ever happen here, it will be in her favour— The idea has never yet occurr’d to her; but it is impossible that it should not occur— And it would be the most ungrateful thing in the world—because—&c.— The Grand-Duchess Catherine detests the French, and the Ambassador made her an excellent answer at the Peterhoff fête last Summer— The Ambassador kept two Country-houses; one at Kammenoi-ostrow, to be near the Emperor, and one on the Peterhoff road, to be near “sa belle”—Madame de Vlodek— The Grand Duchess Catherine rallied him about his fondness for the Peterhoff road— The first time, he was taken by surprize, and got over it as well as he could—but prepared himself for the second. Effectivement, the Grand-Duchess renewed the attack— Oui Madame, je trouve le chemin de Peterhoff charmant— But I have another reason for frequenting it— Comment cela, Monsieur l’Ambassadeur?— Because it enables me the sooner, to receive the news of the frequent victories of l’Empereur mon Maitre— The Ambassador’s Ball last Night was very pleasant and lively— A year ago, he could not have given such a Ball—half the ladies at least, who were there last Evening, a year ago se seraient faites malades—would have sham’d sickness, to decline going— All the women, were of the English and Austrian party—to begin par la maitresse de l’Empereur— But she has no political influence at all— She is the last person in the world through whom any thing could be obtained— Some little place, or trifling favour for any person she might patronize, perhaps might be excepted, but the Emperor makes it a point of honour to allow no political influence to the woman by whom he has children because she is beautiful, and he is young, and fond of pleasure— The Ambassador is going to give another ice-hill party in a few days— Il fait une dépense d’enragé pour cette femme la. (Madame de Vlodek.) The Emperor Napoleon has been unanimously advised by all the persons in his confidence, to this divorce of the Empress— He is going to make his Empire of the West, and will incorporate the whole of Holland with it— How wonderfully, and how steadily he is favoured by Fortune &c!— Mr: Six is very communicative, and I regret very much that he is going away.— He not only gives much information, but says that from which much more important inferences may be drawn— Navarro was not at home— I left his papers and his pamphlet— Mr: Harris told me that M. de Rumigny had called upon him, and asked him, whether the young Gentlemen in my family were “liants”—that he should be glad to be particularly
acquainted with them— To go out with them to the ice-hills &c.— This gives further materials for reflections— I closed my visits by calling upon Mr: Fisher; who has been very ill, but is recovering— In the Evening, I went for the first time to the little Theatre, where I saw a french comic Opera—Monsieur Des Chalumeaux—Music by Gaveaux, and very indifferent—

10. I was again engaged this morning, in visiting a number of Americans whose lodgings I could not yesterday find out. At Mr: Harris’s, I met Mr: M’Murtry, and Mr: Baxter.— We all dined, pass’d the Evening, supp’d, and attended the Ball at Mr: B. Cramer’s— There were about thirty-five persons at dinner, and nearly an hundred at the Ball in the Evening— During the interval between the dinner and supper, I went with Mrs: Adams and paid visits to Countess Litta, Madame Lesseps the French Consul’s Lady, and Madame de Bray— The last only was at home— We found some company there; and I met the Moniteur containing all the official documents relating to the dissolution of marriage between the Emperor Napoleon, and the Empress Josephine— On returning to the Ball, I danced with Mrs: S. Cramer, and with Madame Severin— We supped between two and three in the morning, and it was about 4. when we came home— Near 5 when I went to bed.

11. I had received a card of invitation, and one for Mr: Harris, from Princess Beloselsky, to attend the funeral of the Prince, who died last Sunday night— The hour appointed for attendance at the house was 9. this morning. Mr: Harris not having been yesterday at Mr: Cramer’s as I had expected, I left the card for him at his lodgings last Evening; with an invitation, if he should attend the funeral, to go with me— He came this morning, but it was so late, than when we arrived at the Prince’s house, we found the procession already gone, we soon overtook it however; and reached the Monastery soon after ten O’Clock— The Ceremony resembled in almost all respects that of Mr: Glukoff’s funeral; excepting that it was not so long; that the archbishop who officiated was dressed in more splendid jewelry, and that the Coffin of the Prince had a rich Canopy of purple velvet over it with a coronet on the top— The attendance in this instance was of persons of the highest rank. Of the foreign Ministers, there were only the Duke de Mondragone, Count Schenk, and the Baron de Bussche; all in full dress’d uniform— About twelve the ceremony was finished, and we came home— Mr: Harris told me that he had no invitation from Mr: Cramer yesterday, having had some difference with him arising from their late connection in business— We had several American Gentlemen Messrs: Dana and Coffin, Graham, Baxter Cutts, M’Murtry, Donaldson and Harris to dine with us; and Mr: Harris spent the Evening here— I received this day, a notification that on the new-year’s day Old Stile, there would be a Court held by the Emperor at Noon and a Masquerade Ball in the Evening at 8 O’Clock— At the same time ten red or nobility tickets were sent me for admission at the masquerade

12. I received this day tickets, for Mrs: Adams, myself and Mr: Harris, for the supper to-morrow Evening at the Hermitage Palace— Took this forenoon a long walk round the wharf of the Neva— Met the Emperor twice in a sleigh; he pass’d so rapidly and was so much muffled that I scarcely knew him, untill after he had pass’d— We dined and pass’d the Evening at home. The French Ambassador paid the ladies a visit; and asked us whether we were going to finish the year at the party of the Great Chamberlain Narischkin’s.— We were not— He said it was a great party, always given at that house to close the old year, and usher in the new one— This was the fourth time he should attend it— There were illuminations—a Ball, and a Spectacle; but no special invitations were given.

13. This being New-Year’s day according to the computations of the Greek, which is the Russian Calendar, is observed as a day of great festivity and solemnity— We sent round visiting Cards to all our acquaintance, and to all the persons of distinction who are entitled to be visited; and we received Cards of visitation of the same kind in return— At Noon I went with Mr: Smith, and accompanied also by Mr: Everett to Court, where after the celebration of Mass, which was attended by the Imperial family, the Cercle of the foreign Ministers was held.— The Emperor, Empress, and Empress
Mother, all spoke to me in the most gracious manner— They speak to all the foreign Ministers of the first and second order; but to no others.— After the Cercle was over, and the Court for the Russian nobility which is in another Hall; I was presented with many other foreigners to the two young Princes Nicholas and Michael, brothers of the Emperor; who usually reside with their mother at Gatschina, and have not before been in the City since my arrival here— I was introduced to the two Princes, alone, immediately after Count St: Julien— Mr: Smith and Mr: Everett; with all the other Gentlemen who attended, were presented to them together.— I then went to Mr: Harris’s lodgings, and accompanied by him, called in person at Count Romanzoff’s, Count Soltikoff’s—the French Ambassador’s—M de Gourieff’s—The Grand Chamberlain Narischkin’s, Princess Waezemsky’s (and she alone received us) Count Strogonoff’s, Princess Beloselsky’s, M: de Laval’s— It was now late, and I came home to dinner— About 9 in the Evening I went to the Masquerade at the Palace; with Mrs: Adams— It is called a masquerade, but there are no masques— The imperial family and persons admitted to Court appear, the men in Venitian Domino’s; the Ladies in common Court dresses— All the apartments of the Palace are crowded with people of every description, and in all the dresses of the several provinces of the Empire. The Empress Mother played at cards about two hours— The Emperor and imperial family walk’d the Polonaise through the apartments untill 11. O’Clock, and then went in to the Palace of the Hermitage to the Supper— To this the foreign Ministers, and in the whole about two hundred persons were admitted by special invitation— The supper was served upon several tables— That in the centre appropriated to the imperial family; but at which the French Ambassador, was also seated— The other foreign Ministers had the second table to themselves— Count Severin Potocki, came and took a seat at it, next to me; but was informed that the table was reserved for foreigners; and went to another.— The Emperor pass’d round the table, speaking to about half the persons seated at it— Upon Count St: Julien’s rising, he told him it was contraire à l’etiquette, and that he must keep his seat— He told me that sixteen thousand tickets had been distributed, and that the number of persons who attended was upwards of thirteen thousand— Before one in the morning the Imperial family rose from supper, and returned to the Halls— They soon after retired— We came home before two— At the Court this morning I was informed that some considerable changes had this day been introduced into the organization of the Emperor’s Council of State—and several new appointments to office were announced— Among the rest Count Litta, as Grand Echanson, in the place of the late Prince Beloselsky— I asked the French Ambassador, for half an hour’s conversation with him some day next week; and he agreed to Tuesday morning eleven O’Clock, when I am to call upon him.

14. The weather sat in yesterday, colder than it has yet been this Winter, and still continues so— I paid visits this morning to Mr: Meyer, Messrs: Gluckoff, and Messrs: Raimbert and Montréal— Mr: Gluckoff shewed me a letter from Captain Beckford, at Cronstadt, mentioning the death of two of his men, by the small-pox, on the 9th: and 10th: and that Leighton, his Clerk, lies in extreme danger, with the same disease— At Mr: Raimbert’s I met Mr: Harris, who went with me from thence to call upon Mr: Fisher— We found several of the American Gentlemen with him— Dined at home— In the Evening Madame de Betancourt and her daughter paid a visit to Mrs: Adams, and I went with the Ladies, and visited Madame Colombi, and the Duchess de Serra-Capriola; who is a daughter of Princess Waezemsky. About ten at Night we went to the Ball at Mr: P. Severin’s— I danced Country dances with Mrs: Krehmer, and Miss Dashinka (Dorothy) Smith— At these parties, I am reduced to the necessity of dancing, to avoid gambling at Cards— Mr: Severin introduced to me a Mr: Jacob, a German who has been a professor at the University of Halle—and since, at a Russian University; but who is now about to be employed here in the department of the finances— He has a son,
about eighteen years of age, who has a strong propensity to the life of a sailor, and wished to know of an opportunity to send him upon a voyage to America— I told him that perhaps such an occasion might offer, by Captain Beckford, to whom I would speak upon the subject if he desired— He enquired if I was the writer of the Letters on Silesia, of which he said he had read a German Translation— And also a critique upon them by the literary Journalists of Göttingen— About one in the morning, and before supper, we came home.

15. I had hoped to have this day, to devote almost entirely to writing— But soon after breakfast, I had a visit from Mr: Plumer, with two American Captains; Bell and Salter; which kept me between one and two hours— After them, came Mr: Harris, with Mr: Lohman, an American Citizen, but a native of Bremen— He is going to Amsterdam and to England, and offered to take any letters or packets for America— When these Gentlemen left me, I had barely time for a short walk, untill the day was gone. In the Evening we had a visit from Mr: Six. So that the business of the day resolved itself into the settlement of a few accounts.

16. Mr: Lohman called this morning for his Passport, which I gave him; and he offered to take any letters for America, that I might wish to send; which he would forward from Hamburg, from Holland, or from England. He intends going, to-morrow in the afternoon— His visit this day, delayed me untill almost twelve o’clock, before I went to the French Ambassador’s— He had appointed to see me at eleven— I was however at his house in sufficient time— I told him the object upon which I had wished particularly to converse with him at this time, was the order of the king of Denmark, under which the property of American Citizens, to so large an amount had been sequestered in the Ports of Holstein— That this measure was said to be intended only for the purpose of suppressing an illicit trade between these Ports and the English, and for the condemnation of English property: but in reality it had fallen most oppressively upon American Citizens and American Property— He doubted at first whether he could do any thing in the case; but finally promised to write to his Government the substance of our Conversation, and its object on my part; that the Court of Denmark should restore as speedily as possible the property really American, sequestered, by their late order, and discriminate in its severity between the English and the Americans.— I led the Conversation much into the general subject of the Continental System, and the impolicy of those measures which instead of injuring the English, went to the ruin of all their rivals in commerce, and operated entirely to their advantage— He appeared not to have much information upon the subject; but as far as he understood it, to agree with me in opinion. He supposed that the American Embargo-Law was still in operation— While I was with him, Count Schenck, the Minister of the king of Wurtemberg called; to go out with him to the Ice-Hills— I therefore left him and returned home— At 3 O’Clock I went with the Ladies, to his Country-House at Kammenoi-ostroff— The cold, was at 6 degrees below 0 of Farenheit’s Thermometer— And as by some accident the Ambassador’s own Hills were not in perfect order his company went and used those at the Emperor’s palace about half a mile from the Ambassador’s house— We did not go— About four O’Clock, he came with his Company from the Hills— His Company were as usual, his own Diplomatic Circle, and the family connections of Madame de Vlodek.— There were a few young men whom I had not seen before, and among the rest a Prince Kurakin, son of the Minister of the Interior— In the Evening there was a dance; and Messrs: Rayneval, Rumigny, Lajard, and Loewenstern appeared in female attire— I played at whist, with Count Luxbourg, Mr: Labensky, and Mr: Tettard— About 10. in the Evening, and before supper we came home.

17. I spent the whole day at home—writing in the morning to the Secretary of State; and in the Evening preparing a letter to the Baron de Blome.— Count Einsiedel sent me a packet which he wished to have forwarded by Mr: Lohman. In the Evening we had visits from Mr: Harris; Mr: Coffin, and Mr: Plumer— This afternoon I received from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narischkin an invitation to attend at Court to-morrow morning at 11. O’Clock; unless the parade should be countermanded owing to the severity of the cold— It has been for six days scarcely at any time above Fahrenheit’s 0. untill this Evening, when it moderated— Mr: Lohman who was to have gone this day, wrote me a card that he should not go, untill to-morrow afternoon.

18. On this day was performed the usual solemnity of the benediction of the Waters of the Neva— At 11. O’Clock I attended at Court, according to the notification yesterday received— The foreign Ministers, excepting the French Ambassador, who attended the Emperor on horseback, were first received in the apartments of the Hermitage; and after being there about an hour, went to the anti-chamber usually allotted to them; from the windows of which we saw the procession of the Archbishop and Priests from the Palace through the Admiralty-walk, to the temple below the bridge, where the ceremony was performed. The Emperor and his suite joined the procession— After the ceremony, the two Empresses, with the Princess Amelia of Baden, returned to the Palace, and went upon a balcony which overlooks the river— The troops; to the number of about thirty-two thousand men, filed off before them.— The Court attendants, and the foreign Ministers, went upon the balcony immediately after the Empresses, and remained there untill they retired— There was a collation provided in a corner of the Hall, which opens upon the balcony— The Emperor did not make his appearance at the Palace— The Empresses spoke to all the foreign Ministers, and retired from the Balcony about 3. O’Clock— I returned home and at half-past-four went, and dined at Mr: Meyer’s— There I met Count Einsiedel, Dr: Rogerson, Dr: Wiley, Mr: Venning, Mr: Kavenagh, Mr: Rogerson, and several other English Gentlemen— Mr: Brixner, partner of Mr: Meyer, and Mr: Harris— We sat at table untill 9 O’Clock at Night— I then came home and went with the Ladies to a Ball at Mr: Sebastian Cramer’s— We met here several Americans—the Severin, Krehmer, and Smith families, Mr: Schoenbrun the Swedish Consul and his family; Count Einsiedel, and Messrs: Krabbe, Hennings and Hubsch of the Danish Legation— I played at whist with Mr: H. Severin, Mr: Schoenbrun and Mr: Krehmer— At Supper, which was served between 2 and 3. in the morning, we had the twelfth Night-cake with the bean in it— Mrs: Cramer, asked me if I would take the bean and be king, intimating that it required a treat to the Company in the course of the Winter— I told her I hoped to have the pleasure of treating the company, but that being a Republican it was not suitable for me to be made king— She therefore gave the bean to Count Einsiedel, who chose Mrs: Krehmer for his Queen— The supper was long, and after it the dancing began again— I walked a Polonaise, and danced one Country-dance with Madame Ollier— It was past five O’Clock in the morning when we came home.

19. The fatigue and dissipation of yesterday and the last Night prevented me from getting any sleep, and disabled me for any serious occupation this day— I rose not long before Noon, and after breakfast took a long walk to the Tauridan Palace— I went down upon the river behind it, and after passing round it returned by different Streets from those by which I had gone— Mr: Harris called upon us this Evening— I was somewhat unwell and did not go out.

20. I began again an attempt to write something; but there were too many remnants of dissipation to distract my
attention— I dined with the Chevalier Navarro, and a company of twelve Gentlemen, among whom were General Baron de Stedingk—the Duke de Serra-Capriola, Baron Munck, the Chevalier de Colombi, and the Italian Architect Guaringhi.— I came home early in the Evening— We sent the child to Madame Krehmer’s, who kept the birth-day of one of her children; they did not send him home untill 11. at Night.— We had visits this Evening from Mr: Martin and Mr: Baxter.

21. I took a walk this morning with the intention of going to the Lutheran Church of St: Anne; but it was so distant that when I got there, I found the service was over— I completed then my walk, and on returning home received letters from Mr: Pitcairn at Hamburg, and Mr: Jonathan Russell at Tonning, forwarding Dispatches from the Secretary of State, and a letter from my brother of 6. November—together with other letters for Catherine, for Mr: Gray, and for Mr: J. S. Smith.— I read a Sermon of Massillon— The first of the fourth volume of his Carême. In the Evening, about 10. I went to a party at Mr: Krehmer’s, which I found was a Ball— The Company near a hundred persons— The Ladies did not go— I was almost the first who arrived— I walked the Polonaise, with several of the Ladies, and played whist with Mr: Schoenborn, Mr: Geyer, and a Swedish Officer— I came home about one in the morning; before supper— The party continued untill about 6. in the morning.

22. We were invited for a Ball this Evening at the French Ambassador’s; but received this morning a note postponing the party untill next Saturday, on account of an accident which has befallen Princess Wäezemsky, in falling down stairs— I went this Evening with the Ladies to the German Play, where we saw the fair Millar-maid, from La Molinara—with the music of Paësiello— Mr: Gray who has been very unwell ever since the night of the Mascarade when he walk’d home from the palace, without furs or boots; in the coldest weather that there has been this winter, was this day very ill, and for great part of it confined to his bed.

23. Captain Loring called on me this Morning for a Passport which I gave him, upon his furnishing me Evidence of his being a citizen of the United States and Mr: Bourne’s Passport— I had visits also this morning from Mr: Plumer; and the Captains Bell and Salter, and the Evening from Dr: Graham, Mr: Fisher and Mr: Harris— Mr: Fisher has been for six or seven weeks very unwell; and confined to his chamber; and is but just out— Mr: Harris gave me a ticket for to-morrow Evening, at the Grand-Theatre for the performance of Mademoiselle George, after her return from Moscow. I finally found time to write a Note and a letter to the Baron de Blome, the Danish Minister; upon the affairs of Mr: C. D. Williams and Mr: Jonathan Russell.— I employ the little leisure time I can get in making a translation of the new Constitution of the Russian Council of the Empire, for the Secretary of State.

24. Received from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, a notification that there will be to-morrow a Court, held at the Palace, at Noon; it being the birth day of the Empress— At the same time came from M. de Maisonneuve an invitation for Mrs: Adams, to the Ball of the Empress mother, at 7. in the Evening— This Evening I went to the Theatre with the Ticket for Mr: Harris’s fauteuil, and saw Mademoiselle George in the part of Merope.— She is very handsome, but I think does not perform the character so well as I have seen it rendered by Mademoiselle Saint Val— The after piece was the precieuses Ridicules of Moliere; tolerably well— The house though better lighted than usual was yet very dark— The taste for French Plays is not very great— Mlle: George was called for after the Tragedy was over, and came forward to receive applause.

25. At Noon I went to the palace, and attended the Court, which was held between one and two O’Clock. The foreign Ministers did not attend at the Mass— The Emperor, Empress, and Empress-Mother, as usual, spoke to all the foreign Ministers— The Emperor asked me if I had received any late news from America— I told him I had yesterday received accounts to the 3d: of December New Stile; with the Message from the President of the United States to Congress at the opening of the Session— After the Court was over I came home, and wrote untill near 5. O’Clock, when I went and dined with the Chevalier de Bray— He was unwell, and did not attend at the Court— The French Ambassador and Consul were there— The Duke de Mondragone, and some others, with the family— Between 7. and 8 I came home, and went immediately to the Palace, with Mrs: Adams to the Ball of the Empress Mother— It was exactly like that which she gave on the Emperor’s birth-day, excepting that the company was not so numerous— The Empress-Mother again spoke to most of her guests before, at, and after supper— The Emperor and Empress spoke occasionally, and to particular persons— The supper was indifferent—served about midnight— And about 2. in the morning the Imperial family retired, and the company immediately dispersed.

26. I had a succession of visits this morning, from Mr: Montréal who found us at breakfast, from Captain Beckford, from Mr Baxter and from Mr: Harris, which, with a short walk, employed the day untill dinner— Mr: Harris called again in the Evening, and invited me to dine with him to-morrow at the English Club.

27. After passing all the morning at the translation of the Constitution for the Council, I went with Mr: Harris and dined at the English Club; an institution like that of the Casino at Berlin— I met there Mr: Cutts and Mr: Martin—Mr: Krehmer, and Mr: Gervais, a Secretary of Count Romanzoff’s.— After dinner I pass’d an hour in perusing the latest french newspapers, and came home— Then went with Mr: Smith and visited the two Messrs: Cramer, and the two Messrs: Severin. At Mr: B. Cramer’s we were received, and spent an hour— About 10. we went to the Ball at the French Ambassador’s. The Ladies did not go— There were about seventy persons present—one of his very small parties— The Danish Minister Baron de Blome told me he had dispatched my letters to him— I had much conversation with General Pardo, who upon a permission of absence is going to Moscow, and with the Duke de Mondragone, who is going in two or three days for Paris— General Pardo told me that he had translated many of the Odes of Horace into Greek, with the same measures as the Originals— And had made an original Greek epigram, in honour of the Queen of Prussia, much to her gratification— Prince Alexander Galitzin, Procureur du Saint Synode, told us that last Night an opera was performed at the Great Theatre, called Lisistrata ou les Athéniennes imitated from Aristophanes, which was so indecent that several Ladies left the House in the midst of the performance— I came home about one in the morning; before supper— The party continued untill about five.

28— We have at length got through the continual series of invitations, which have so long kept us in a State of dissipation, and absorbed my time, in a manner the most opposite to my wishes and my judgment— I pass’d this day altogether at home, excepting the time taken for a walk of exercise— I read a Sermon of Massillon— On the immutability of the divine Law—the Second in the fourth volume of his Carême— I resumed also the Russian Grammar, and learnt something further of the Characters of the Alphabet.— My correspondence however continues greatly in arrear, and I know not whether I shall ever entirely bring it up.

29. Mr: Baxter called upon Me this morning, and informed me that he wished to go on Thursday morning, and as he is to take dispatches for me, requested me to procure for him a Courier’s Passport; for which I promised to apply for him to Count Romanzoff— Mr: Shreve also called upon me, and wished to obtain a similar Passport for a Mr: Berry, second mate of the Bark William Grey, who is going to Copenhagen— He concluded finally to have the name inserted, as Mr: Baxter’s servant in his Passport.— Excepting the time taken by these interruptions I passed all the morning in writing— In the Evening I went to the German Play; and saw Das Kind der Liebe of Kotzebue— I had seen it before at Berlin— The House was very thin— Two of the performers were called out; but the best actress was not. On coming home I found Madame de Bray, with Madame Loewenstern, and her daughter Lise, on a visit to our Ladies—

30. I finished this morning the Translation of the new Constitution of the Russian Council— Mr: Shreve called upon me with Mr: Berry to whom I delivered his Passport— I was employed all the Morning and untill 3. P.M. in writing— After which I took a walk of about six miles— I find by my usual admeasurement of the time which it takes me to walk a given distance, that the quay of the Neva from the Winter Palace to the foundery, is 1 mile and 1/5— In the Evening I wrote a note to the Chancellor Count Romanzoff, requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr: Baxter, and his servant, William Berry— Mr: Harris pass’d most of the Evening with us.

31. Engaged all the morning, in writing to the Secretary of State, to send by Mr: Baxter— In the Evening we all went to the Great Theatre, where we saw Rusalka, the Nymph of the Dnieper— The fourth part— A great Russian Opera. Its character resembles much the English Pantomimes— With a variety of Scenery—the action extravagantly romantic— The ballets indifferent, and the music still more so— Mr: Shreve called again after we returned from the play— But our letters were not yet ready for him.

Day— I rise at 8 or 9. in the morning— Read and write untill ten or more commonly eleven, which is our usual hour for Breakfast— After that I read and write again, or receive, or pay visits untill 3. P.M— Then walk one or two hours, dine about 5— Pass the Evening sometimes in Company abroad; sometimes at the Theatre— About Midnight is our common hour for retiring to bed— But this has during the past month been frequently protracted untill three, four, and sometimes five in the morning— Having gone through the course of invitations which we were to expect, we may promise ourselves for the future a more tranquil life. My time hitherto has been wasted almost entirely.
